instruction: In the ink content measurement system, what kinds of spectrum were used?
Output: In the ink content measurement system, the researchers used visible spectrum.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to preprocess the collected spectral signal in the ink content measurement system?
Output: Successive Projections Algorithm (SPA) and Competitive Adaptive Reweighted Sampling (CARS) algorithm were used for spectral feature processing in the ink content measurement system.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the prediction effect of the primary color ink content models in the ink content measurement system?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the prediction effect of the primary color ink content models in the ink content measurement system is the Cross-Validation Root Mean Square Error (RMSECV) and coefficient of determination (R2).

instruction: What machine learning algorithms were used to build the prediction models for primary color ink content in the ink content measurement system?
Output: The machine learning algorithms used to build the prediction models for primary color ink content in the ink content measurement system are Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR) and Support Vector Regression (SVR).

instruction: Can the CARS feature extraction algorithm be used to preprocess the collected ink content spectrum information and extract characteristic wavelengths for building prediction models in the ink content measurement system?
Output: Yes, the CARS (Competitive Adaptive Reweighted Sampling) feature extraction algorithm can be used to preprocess the collected ink content spectrum information and extract characteristic wavelengths for building prediction models in the ink content measurement system. According to the related study, the CARS algorithm was used along with the Successive Projections Algorithm (SPA) to extract characteristic wavelengths from the preprocessed information. The test results showed that the CARS-SVR algorithm models had the best prediction effect, indicating that the CARS algorithm successfully extracted relevant features from the ink content spectrum information.
